I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) country programming mission to India in 2010 
made provision for technical assistance (TA) in septage management,1 in response to a request 
from the government for assistance in urban sanitation. The country operations business plan 
for 2011–2013 confirmed the processing of the TA.2 
 
2.  An ADB fact-finding mission discussed the TA with the Ministry of Urban Development 
(MOUD) from 30 June to 12 July 2011. This report is based on the understandings reached 
regarding  the  impact,  outcome,  output,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing 
arrangements, and outline terms of reference for the TA. The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Better access to adequate sanitation is a national priority of the government. Inadequate 
sanitation costs the economy about $53.8 billion a year, according to a recent study.4 The 
impact manifests itself mainly in health problems, in the extra time that goes into meeting 
sanitation needs, in potential service revenues lost, and in the negative economic impact on 
tourism. The Millennium Development Goal for sanitation enjoins governments to extend access 
to improved sanitation to at least 50% of the urban population by 2015 and to the entire urban 
population by 2025. The National Urban Sanitation Policy (NUSP) issued by MOUD in 2008 
identifies the following key policy issues: (i) low awareness of the links between sanitation and 
public health; (ii) considerable gaps and overlaps in institutional roles and responsibilities at the 
national,  state,  and  city  levels;  (iii) lack  of  an  integrated  citywide  approach;  (iv) limited 
technology choices;5 and (v) unresponsiveness to demand, especially from the unserved and 
the poor. To transform urban India into community-driven, totally sanitary, healthy, and livable 
cities and towns, the NUSP defines these specific policy goals: (i) generating awareness and 
behavioral  change,  (ii) achieving  open-defecation-free  cities,  and  (iii) integrating  sanitation 
citywide. 
 
4.  On-site  sanitation.  Improving  and  maintaining  the  level  of  sanitation  services  has 
become increasingly challenging. Historically, the government focused on centralized sewerage 
systems and wastewater treatment plants, and did not prioritize on-site sanitation. Wastewater 
disposal through conventional sewerage, however, is not always the technically best solution or 
the most cost effective. Demographic and geographic constraints make conventional sewerage 
technically unfeasible and financially unaffordable. Particularly in peri-urban and tourist sites 
away from densely populated developed areas, on-site sanitation, including proper septage 
management, is an alternative. One study of urban areas in India showed that a significant part 
of  the  population  relies  on  on-site  sanitation  and  proper  septage  management;  29%  of 
households are connected to a septic tank, while 17% use other on-site sanitation systems like 
pit or vault latrines.6 The NUSP has changed the country’s approach to urban sanitation, and

mandates local governments to undertake behavioral change toward total sanitation—100%

5.  Collection, transportation, treatment, and disposal. The NUSP emphasizes the need 
for adequate septage management to achieve the goal of 100% safe sanitation. Urban local 
bodies (ULBs) are expected to develop strategies for full access to improved sanitation, through 
their city sanitation plans (CSPs), that address the technical issues and are associated with 
financially implementable plans. If a centralized sewerage system is not technically or financially 
justified, even for limited areas, the NUSP calls for ULBs and states to issue policies and 
provide technical solutions to on-site sanitation and septage management. Very few cities in 
India, however, have the physical capacity to safely collect, transport, and treat urban human 
waste. As a result, septic tanks and latrines in urban areas have become major sources of 
groundwater and surface water pollution, with significant negative impact on the environment, 
public health, and the economy. Appropriate policy and technical guidelines are needed to 
promote the use of such systems and extend the benefits of improved sanitation and better 
public health to more people. The Technical Guidance Note on Septage Management in Indian 
Cities,  now  being  prepared  by  MOUD,  explicitly  requires  all  ULBs  to  prepare  a  septage 
management plan (SMP) as part of their CSP. 
 
6.  The need for proper septage management has been confirmed during the preparation 
and implementation of ADB-funded loan projects. Sewerage development does not always 
cover the entire ULB area, and the remaining non-sewered areas have demanded improved 
on-site sanitation, despite its not being part of the scope of the projects. Septage treatment is 
one of the on-site sanitation options, and it requires proper management. Also, ULBs need 
support in putting a septage management service into operation by developing management 
plans  and  implementation  schemes  for  on-site  sanitation.  The  proposed  TA  will  therefore 
support the pilot ULBs in Mizoram and Himachal Pradesh in developing SMPs with CSPs and in 
implementing, on a pilot scale, on-site sanitation systems using international best practices,7 
particularly in tourist destinations. ADB supported the development of infrastructure in the two 
states under the North-Eastern Region Capital Cities Development Investment Program and the 
Infrastructure Development Investment Program for Tourism.8 It has been recognized that the 
provision of sanitation facilities such as public toilets under the ADB-funded tourism project has 
demanded proper operation and management, which requires the concerned ULBs to conduct 
appropriate septage management. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  access  to  proper  sanitation  facilities  for 
non-sewered  urban  areas,  as  measured  by  the  number  of  ULBs  implementing  adequate 
septage management practices according to an acceptable SMP. The target number is 10. The 
outcome will be the recognition by the four selected ULBs of the importance of appropriate 
sanitation  and  septage  management  incorporating  best  practices.  Such  recognition  will  be 
measured by the quality of the CSPs and SMPs approved by the four ULBs and the urban 
development departments of the states of Mizoram and Himachal Pradesh.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Development of Draft City Sanitation Plans for Pilot Cities 
8.  The TA will support the development of draft CSPs for four ULBs in the states of 
Mizoram and Himachal Pradesh. The output will comprise the following: (i) situation analysis, 
(ii) draft CSPs, and (iii) CSPs upgraded through consultations. The four ULBs—Aizawl and 
Lunglei in Mizoram, and Mandi and Parwanoo in Himachal Pradesh—were identified at the 
initiative of the urban development departments of the states, which expect the benefits to 
complement those from  ongoing  projects  such  as  the  North-Eastern Region  Capital  Cities 
Development Investment Program and the Infrastructure Development Investment Program for 
Tourism  (footnote 8).  Aizawl’s  draft  CSP  needs  to  be  updated  and  strengthened  for 
non-sewered  areas.  The  three  other  ULBs  will  need  comprehensive  situation  analysis  in 
preparation for CSP development. 
 
9.  A citywide, total-sanitation, and inclusive approach to CSP preparation will be taken. A 
city-level implementation committee will be established to oversee the activities. The members 
of the committee will be government officials and representatives of business and commercial 
communities, academe, civil society, nongovernment organizations, industry, and residents. 
Consultations will be managed by the committee with the support of consultants. 
 
2.  Development of Draft Septage Management Plans for Pilot Cities or Areas 
10.  The TA will also support the drafting of an SMP with a manual of practice for one ULB in 
each  of  the  two  states.  The  ULBs  will  be  selected  during  the  preparation  of  the  CSPs, 
considering the need for septage management. Links to ongoing projects will be considered as 
well.  The  management  plans  might  be  citywide  or  area-wide,  depending  on  the  need  for 
septage management and its feasibility, as determined in the CSPs. During this exercise, 
appropriate  performance  indicators  will  be  scrutinized,  in  addition  to  the  service-level 
benchmarks being developed by MOUD.  
 
3.  Support for Septage Management Plan Implementation in the Pilot Areas 
11.  This TA will carry out a pilot scheme to verify the feasibility of the SMPs, with a manual 
of practice also to be developed under this TA. The pilot implementation may be done at sites of 
new investment in ongoing projects. Since the private sector has a critical role in septage 
management,  a  public–private  partnership  scheme  will  be  explored.  In  addition,  pilot 
demonstration of the johkasou system9 may be considered for any tourist destination if feasibility 
is confirmed through an SMP. 
 
4.  Conduct of Training and Workshops 
12.  A series of consultations will be held with relevant stakeholders in the course of CSP 
development. In addition, training and workshops will be provided in the two pilot cities to 
disseminate the essence of the SMPs, and to implement the plan in a sustainable manner. 
                                                
9  The johkasou (anaerobic filtration) system is an on-site sanitation technology option commonly used in sparsely 
populated areas in Japan where sewerage is not viable or cost effective. Each compact package unit (per house or 
per small community) carries out both anaerobic and aerobic treatment and final disinfection, with the final effluent 
being discharged directly into local drains. System operation requires some power consumption.

4 
Japanese  best  practices  in  septage  management  at  remote  tourist  destinations  will  be 
disseminated through workshops in both states and in New Delhi. 
 
C.  Assumptions and Risks 
13.  As mentioned, the NUSP requires all ULBs to draw up adequate septage management 
strategies through their CSPs. The TA assumes that the pilot ULBs are eager to fulfill the 
requirements  and  exercise  adequate  ownership. On  the  other  hand,  there  is  the  risk that 
stakeholders, including residents, may be unwilling to accept a septage management option, 
though  it  is  technically  justified.  A  centralized  sewerage  system  might  be  deemed  more 
attractive because of its convenience. The consultations for CSP preparation and the proposed 
pilot schemes will demonstrate the feasibility of the on-site sanitation option, to make the public 
more  aware  of  the  effectiveness  of  this  option  when  combined  with  appropriate  septage 
management. The social development and communication specialist will identify the target 
stakeholders, as well as the need of training for the purpose. 
 
D.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
$700,000  equivalent,  and  administered  by  ADB.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart 
support in the form of office space, the remuneration of counterpart staff, including field per 
diems and transportation costs, and other in-kind contributions (Appendix 2). 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MOUD will be the executing agency for the TA. The urban development departments of 
Mizoram  and  Himachal  Pradesh  will  be  the  implementing  agencies,  and  will  support  the 
successful completion of the TA. Four ULBs—Mandi and Parwanoo in Himachal Pradesh, and 
Aizawl and Lunglei in Mizoram—have been identified for the study. 
 
16.  The government will provide (i) all relevant documents, data, statistics, information, and 
maps that are at its disposal; (ii) appropriate and qualified counterpart staff, including their field 
per diems and transportation costs; (iii) a project director from MOUD, to be assigned before the 
consultants mobilize; (iv) office accommodation and office equipment, including desks, chairs, 
local communication, and water and electricity costs; (v) logistic assistance in the training and 
workshops; and (vi) facilitation of communication support from the participating ULBs. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2012 to December 2013, 
including the recruitment of consultants but not financial closure. It is assumed that 3 months 
will be required to obtain confirmation from the government after approval. The TA will use 
48 person-months  of  national  consultants’  input,  and  2 person-months  of  input  from  an 
international expert to introduce international best practices in septage management, focusing 
on remote areas such as tourist destinations. The international expert will be provided by the 
Japan Sanitation Consortium under a separate (partnership) agreement to be entered into with 
ADB once the TA is approved. The outline terms of reference for the consultants is in Appendix 
3. 
 
18.  The  consultants  will  be  hired  by  ADB  according  to  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Two teams of consultants will be hired for 
the states of Himachal Pradesh and Mizoram, mostly through a firm and through quality- and 
cost-based selection (at an 80:20 ratio) using biodata technical proposals. Other consultants will

5 
be  hired  individually,  also  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants. 
Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  conform  to  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Upon  TA  completion,  all  equipment 
purchased under the TA will be handed over to MOUD or to the implementing agencies through 
MOUD. 
 
19.  Workshops  and  training  sessions  for  relevant  government  officials,  nongovernment 
organizations, civil society groups, and local business communities—the main stakeholders— 
will be an important component of this TA. The workshops and training will be held to improve 
awareness and understanding of septage management. TA findings will be disseminated during 
the workshops and training sessions, as well as during the consultations. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Introducing 
Best Practices for Septage Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  objective  of  the  assignment  is  to  assist  the  government  in  establishing  an 
appropriate  implementation  scheme for  septage  management  through  the  provision  of  city 
sanitation plans (CSPs) with septage management plans (SMPs) and manuals of practice, 
focusing  on  collection,  treatment,  and  disposal,  as  well  as  introducing  international  best 
practices in septage management. In addition, this technical assistance (TA) will explore the 
development  of  performance  indicators,  which  are  supposed  to  be  used  as  service-level 
benchmarks for septage. Specific output will comprise: (i) draft CSPs for pilot cities, (ii) draft 
SMPs,  (iii) the  implementation  of  a  pilot  scheme  in  pilot  areas,  (iv) training  for  relevant 
stakeholders, and (v) workshops to disseminate the lessons learned from the pilot schemes and 
international best practices. The scope of works for consultants and terms of reference for each 
consultant are presented below. 
 
2.  The  TA  will  require  about  48  person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  The 
consultants will be hired by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) according to its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Separate sets of consultants will 
recruited for Himachal Pradesh and Mizoram states, through a firm or individually, except for the 
knowledge management and training specialist and the technical adviser, who will work for both 
states. In addition to these consultants, an international expert in sanitation will be hired to 
introduce international best practices in septage management in Japan, by agreement with the 
Japan Sanitation Consortium. 
 
A.  Specific Tasks of Consultants 
 
1.  Draft City Sanitation Plan 
 
3.  The consultants will develop CSPs for selected cities in consultation with the Ministry of 
Urban Development (MOUD) and urban local bodies (ULBs). First, the consultants will review 
the current status of planning and implementation of sanitation improvement programs in the 
four pilot cities—Aizawl and Lunglei in Mizoram, and Mandi and Parwanoo in Himachal Pradesh. 
The consultants are expected to communicate with consultants working under two ADB-funded 
projects, namely, the North-Eastern Region Capital Cities Development Investment Program, 
and Infrastructure Development Investment Program for Tourism.1 Once the status of sanitation 
improvement in the two ULBs in each state is confirmed (possibly suggesting that a sewerage 
development plan may exist but may not cover the entire area, and that on-site sanitation may 
be considered), the consultants will prepare the draft CSPs. Then appropriate consultation 
procedures will be carried out to accommodate the needs of stakeholders and to finalize the 
CSP. The detailed procedures should be confirmed before implementation in accordance with 
the  procedures  executed  by  other  development  partners  such  as  the  World  Bank,  the 
Department for International Development of the United Kingdom, the United States Agency for 
International  Development,  and  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA).  The 
consultants may coordinate with the JICA sanitation expert in MOUD.

2.  Draft Septage Management Plan 
 
4.  In parallel with CSP preparation, the consultants will develop SMPs for two ULBs in each 
state. The SMPs should address the design of septic tanks or pits, the method of approval of 
building plans or retrofitting  of existing installations to comply with rules,  the periodicity of 
de-sludging  and  operation  and  maintenance  of  installations,  the  methods  and  locations  of 
transport and disposal, revenue sources for septage management (such as tariffs, cess, and 
taxes), and penalty clauses for untreated discharges. The management plan will include a 
manual of practice to define the operational day-to-day procedures including, but not limited to, 
proper pumping equipment operation and worker safety, site control (including post-pumping 
cleanup),  transport  requirements  (including  rules  of  the  road),  disposal  procedures  at  the 
treatment facility, and record keeping. Technical, financial, and organizational requirements 
should be described to ensure environmental sustainability. In addition, several performance 
indicators  will  be  examined  for  feasibility  and  practicality.  It  is  expected  that  performance 
indicator(s) will be proposed as service level benchmarks at the end of the TA. As for the 
performance indicators, the consultants are required to maintain close consultation with MOUD. 
 
  3.  Implementation of Pilot Schemes 
 
5.  After drafting the SMPs, including a manual of practice, the consultants will prepare a 
pilot scheme in one of two ULBs in each state. The purpose of the pilot scheme is to finalize the 
SMP and the manual of practice by evaluating and revising the terms and conditions described 
in the SMP. The pilot scheme may include not only the technical aspect but also financial 
sustainability, such as an attempt to ring-fence the expenditure with projected revenues from 
tariffs or cess. A public–private partnership scheme is also envisaged under this pilot scheme. 
 
  4.  Conduct of Workshops and Training 
 
6.  The consultants will develop the training materials on the basis of lessons learned from 
the development of the CSPs and SMPs. In addition, the implementation of pilot schemes will 
have explicit input into the training materials, in addition to input from the review of any available 
training materials, tool kits, and publications. The consultants will also organize workshops to 
disseminate the output of the TA, and to introduce international best practices from Japan. Best 
practices for tourist destinations are expected to be presented. 
 
B.  Individual Terms of Reference 
 
7.  The  consultants  will  be  procured  in  two  packages,  one  team  for  each  state.  Both 
packages will consist of the same experts, except for the experts for training and workshops, 
and  the  technical  adviser  for  septage.  International  experts  from  the  Japan  Sanitation 
Consortium will be hired through separate agreements. 
 
1.  Sanitation Management Specialist and Team Leader (national; 
9 person-months for each state) 
8.  The expert should have a postgraduate degree in civil or environmental engineering or 
urban planning or an equivalent degree, with at least 10 years’ broad experience in sewerage 
and sanitation management, preferably on-site sanitation. In addition, the expert should have 
experience in developing and reviewing management policies and guidelines on sanitation. The 
specialist should also be conversant with private sector operations in sanitation and waste 
management. In collaboration with other experts, this specialist will carry out the following:

Appendix 3  11 
(i)  Exercise  overall  management  of  this  TA,  including  communications  between 
MOUD, the ULBs, and ADB; 
(ii)  Review relevant national and international best practices identified, and evaluate 
their relevance and replicability for documentation; 
(iii)  Develop  and  propose  CSPs,  SMPs,  and  manuals  of  practice  for  septage 
management; 
(iv)  Propose  performance  indicators  and  evaluate  their  practicability  through 
consultations and pilot implementation; 
(v)  Review the potential areas for pilot implementation and develop the pilot scheme; 
(vi)  Conduct the pilot scheme;  
(vii)  Supervise the training and workshops; and 
(viii)  Explore  a  public–private  partnership  scheme  to  increase  financial  and 
operational sustainability. 
 
2.  Environmental or Municipal Engineer (national; 6 person-months for each 
state) 
9.  The expert should be a postgraduate engineer with at least 5 years’ experience in urban 
water  and  sanitation  or  wastewater  management,  preferably  the  planning  and  design  of 
sanitation  facilities  and  conveyance,  the  treatment  and  possible  reuse  of  household  liquid 
wastes, and the disposal of human excreta. Experience in the design and implementation of 
citywide programs for the collection, transportation, treatment, and disposal of wet waste is 
highly desirable. Experience in city-level planning and working with urban community groups will 
be an advantage. The expert will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Support the sanitation management specialist in preparing all documents and 
output as required; 
(ii)  Explore the possibility of recovering energy and nutrients and recycling treated 
sewerage to increase financial sustainability; 
(iii)  Assist  the  sanitation  management  specialist  in  exploring  a  public–private 
partnership scheme through the provision of engineering input; 
(iv)  Compare the existing sanitation system with the proposed septage management 
system on the basis of technical, economical, and social and environmental 
factors; and 
(v)  Support stakeholder consultation by communicating the alternatives considered, 
the reasons behind the choice of the preferred alternative, and likely scenarios of 
negative impact if the system does not operate as desired. 
 
3.  Social Development and Communication Specialist (national; 
2 person-months for each state) 
10.  The expert should have a postgraduate degree in the social sciences, with at least 
5 years’  experience  in  community  mobilization,  participatory  planning,  communication,  and 
advocacy. Experience in working with urban communities in the field of water and sanitation is 
required, while experience with urban poor communities is preferred. The expert will carry out 
the following: 
(i)  Organize consultation meetings as required; 
(ii)  Identify and mobilize stakeholders through participatory processes as required; 
(iii)  Develop an awareness program for septage management; 
(iv)  Support the knowledge management and training specialist in developing training 
materials and programs for dissemination workshops; and

12  Appendix 3 
(v)  Ensure  women’s  equal  participation  in  all  consultative  and  decision-making 
processes supported under the capacity development technical assistance, in 
line with the targets set out in the design and monitoring framework. 
 
4.  Municipal Finance and Institutional Specialist (national; 3 person-months 
for each state) 
11.  The  expert  should  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  public  finance  or  equivalent 
background, with at least 10 years’ broad experience in municipal finance, institutional analysis, 
and governance issues, particularly in relation to local government agencies. Experience in 
working with any state government and ULBs in public finance for public utility services will be 
essential. The expert will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Review all relevant legal provisions, bylaws, and rules relating to urban sanitation 
and septage; 
(ii)  Review the legal soundness of the proposed SMPs and manuals of practice; 
(iii)  Provide input to develop all output, such as the CSPs, SMPs, and manuals of 
practice; 
(iv)  Prepare action plans for the ULBs’ bylaws and rules to implement the proposed 
plans and manuals; and 
(v)  Support the knowledge management and training specialist in developing training 
materials and programs for dissemination workshops. 
 
5.  Knowledge Management and Training Specialist (national; 
2 person-months) 
12.  The expert should have broad experience in developing and implementing awareness, 
dissemination, advocacy, and training programs for state governments and ULBs. Experience in 
urban utilities is preferable. The expert will cover both states and will carry out the following 
tasks: 
(i)  Identify trainees for the septage management training program; 
(ii)  Develop  the  training  materials  on  the  basis  of  input  from  consulting  team 
members; 
(iii)  Develop an effective training program for each group of stakeholders; 
(iv)  Organize workshops to disseminate the output of this TA; and 
(v)  Organize  workshops  to  introduce  international  best  practices  from  Japan,  in 
consultation with the international expert on sanitation. 
 
6.  Technical Adviser for Septage Operation (national; 1 person-month) 
13.  The  expert  should  have  experience  in  the  operation  of  on-site  sanitation,  and  a 
mechanical engineering background. The expert will provide technical advice from time to time 
and confirm the technical feasibility of all output including the CSPs, SMPs, and manuals of 
practice. The expert will cover the two states. 
 
7.   On-Site Sanitation Specialist (international; 2 person-months) 
14.  The  expert(s)  should  have  experience  in  on-site  sanitation  management  in  Japan, 
preferably in tourist destinations. The expert(s) will demonstrate international best practices in 
on-site sanitation from Japan in workshops and prepare the materials to be disseminated; 
provide professional input on SMPs, manuals of practice, and training materials; prepare an 
assessment report on the applicability in India of emerging sanitation management practices in

Appendix 3  13 
Japan to be distributed at the workshops; and provide financial and institutional knowledge on 
the septage management. 
 
15.  The above expertise and input are indicative, and may be adjusted in consultation with 
the government and ADB after the submission of the detailed work plan from both packages, 
which may require substitute or supplemental input complete all works described in an efficient 
manner. Thus, there is provision for unallocated national consultants’ input of 5 person-months, 
to be utilized as needed during TA implementation. These additional experts may be hired 
through individual consultant selection. 
 
C.  Reporting 
 
16.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 1.5 months 
after the mobilization of the team leader, finalizing the approach including the selection of ULBs, 
a detailed work plan, and the implementation schedule for the TA; (ii) a draft interim report 
within 5 months after the mobilization of the team leader including draft CSPs, SMPs, and an 
implementation plan for the pilot scheme; (iii) an interim report 6 months after the mobilization of 
the team leader, to include updates of draft interim reports; (iv) progress reports after 8 and 
12 months of training and workshops, summarizing the progress of training and workshops as 
well as draft materials to be finalized as output; (v) a draft final report 12 months after the 
mobilization  of  the  team  leader,  presenting  all  activities  undertaken,  results  achieved,  an 
assessment  of  achievements  compared  with  the  original  targets,  a  review  of  problems 
encountered during implementation, and action taken or proposed to be taken to remedy these 
problems, and proposing recommendations in addition to output such as final CSPs, SMPs, and 
other related documents; and (vi) a final report 1 month after the receipt of comments on the 
draft final report from the government and ADB, satisfying all requirements of the TA. This 
reporting schedule is indicative and will be finalized on the basis of the proposal of consultants 
within the entire TA schedule. 
 
17.  The consultants will assist MOUD and the ULBs in organizing all necessary consultation 
meetings, training sessions, and workshops as required. The consultants will brief MOUD, the 
ULBs, and any relevant agencies and appropriate stakeholders on the TA through various 
opportunities.
